Unpopular Opinion: You can clearly determine how well your Marketing is "working" without ever looking at attribution. 

And the way to get there is by focusing on *business KPIs* 

TTM Growth Rate %
GTM Efficiency % 
Total Pipeline Created
Total Investment to Create Pipe 
Pipeline Opp Win Rate 
Investments to Create Pipe : Total Pipe Created

And boom: you'll get a clear picture that aligns everyone in GTM on the current performance and historical trends. 

Example $100MM ARR SaaS Company:

Growth rate: 24% (decent growth)
GTM Efficiency: 428% (highly inefficient)
Total Pipe Created: $48MM
Total Investment to Create Pipe: $27.6MM
Pipeline Opp Win Rate: 8% (down from 12% YoY)
Pipeline:Spend Ratio : $1.74 (really bad) 

You don't need to build a multi-touch attribution report. Or split the credit between "Inbound" and "Outbound". Or debate how much "brand value" is created from all the trade show booths. None of it. 

This performance is abysmal and unsustainable. If continued for several more years, this company will undoubtedly crash and burn. Alarms should have been going off at the Exec level and Board level for the past 4+ quarters. 

Yet, the Marketing QBR reports show increasing MQL performance, great cost/MQL, and an overly complicated influenced revenue report that shows how well everything is working (yet nobody really understands). 

All of the Marketing reports are built by Managers and Directors who have little to no visibility into the broader business context - that growth is slowing and CAC has inflated by almost 3X in the past 6 quarters. 

__

As a Finance or GTM Executive, you cannot rely on bottoms-up department-level reporting to build and optimize your GTM. Instead, you *must*:

1. Align on a Unified set of GTM KPIs that don't rely on attribution 
2. Start with Investor Level & Financial Level KPIs, particularly growth rate and GTM Efficiency % 
3. Break the investments and performance down across the customer lifecycle (not by the GL / Dept code) 
4. Analyze the performance, historical trends, and unit economics across each core phase of the customer lifecycle. 
5. Rapidly identify the biggest issues and opportunities to unlock growth and ROI.
6. Map and track strategic priorities against BUSINESS KPIs (not attribution)

Then, with all of this BUSINESS CONTEXT. You can start to run custom diagnostics with W-shaped attribution, or linear, or signal-based, or sliced by GEO / segment / vertical or anything else to answer specific questions you have based on the business KPIs. 

Always look at attribution data with a purpose based on business-level KPIs. 

#finance #b2b #sales #marketing #gtm

__

p.s. I know some people will misinterpret this message, so I'm proactively clarifying: I've never told people not to use attribution tools. Instead, I've always been vocal and communicated the clear patterns of problems B2B companies run into based on how they use these tools and data. It's a process problem, not a technology problem.

-9 additional months in Marketing headcount

Bottoms Up GTM Analytics: Data and reporting is generated & analyzed from each budget holder then assembled into a department-level deck then again assembled into one large GTM report.

-Conflicting findings across teams & departments
-Way too tactical & complicated for executives to understand & make decisions
-Core objective is to prove/justify how well everything is performing

- Focus on micro-optimizations and tactical changes
- Loses sight of the bigger picture

- Indecision / Inaction
- Misalignment across the GTM teams around what to do next

Tops-Down GTM Analytics: Data and reporting starts with *business metrics* and systematically works down to departments and budget holders, leveraging a standardized and consistent reporting structure across the entire GTM.

-Strategic & transformational changes
